sen.j: 奥平 家昌（おくだいら いえまさ、天正5年（1577年）- 慶長19年10月10日 (旧暦)（1614年11月11日））は、安土桃山時代から江戸時代前期にかけての武将、大名。
sen.e: Iemasa OKUDAIRA (1577 - November 11, 1614) was busho (Japanese military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) who lived from the Azuchi-Momoyama period toward the early Edo period.
Iemasa OKUDAIRA (1577 - November 11, 1614) was a busho (Japanese military commander) and a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) who lived from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period.
Iemasa OKUDAIRA (1577 - November 11, 1614) was a busho (Japanese military commander) and a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) who lived from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period.

sen.j: 下野国宇都宮藩主（第26代宇都宮城主）。
sen.e: He was the lord of the Utsunomiya Domain, Shimotsuke Province (the 26th lord of Utsunomiya-jo Castle).
He was the lord of the Utsunomiya Domain, Shimotsuke Province (the 26th lord of Utsunomiya-jo Castle).
He was the lord of the Utsunomiya Domain, Shimotsuke Province (the 26th lord of Utsunomiya-jo Castle).

sen.j: 美濃国加納藩主・奥平信昌の長男。
sen.e: He was the eldest son of Nobumasa OKUDAIRA who was the lord of the Kano Domain, Mino Province.
He was the eldest son of Nobumasa OKUDAIRA who was the lord of the Kano Domain, Mino Province.
He was the eldest son of Nobumasa OKUDAIRA, the lord of the Kano Domain, Mino Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 母は徳川家康の長女・亀姫 (盛徳院)。
sen.e: His mother was Kame-hime (Seitokuin), who was the eldest daughter of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
His mother was Kame-hime (Seitokuin), who was the eldest daughter of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
His mother was Kame-hime (Seitokuin), the eldest daughter of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 正室は本多忠勝の次女・法明院。
sen.e: His lawful wife was Homyoin, the second daughter of Tadakatsu HONDA.
His lawful wife was Homyoin, the second daughter of Tadakatsu HONDA.
His lawful wife was Homyoin, the second daughter of Tadakatsu HONDA.

sen.j: 子は奥平忠昌（長男）、ビン姫（徳川秀忠の養女、堀尾忠晴正室）。
sen.e: He had children, Tadamasa OKUDAIRA (the eldest son) and Bin hime (adopted by Hidetada TOKUGAWA and became the lawful wife of Tadaharu HORIO).
He had children, Tadamasa OKUDAIRA (the eldest son) and Bin hime (adopted by Hidetada TOKUGAWA and became the lawful wife of Tadaharu HORIO).
His children were: Tadamasa OKUDAIRA (the eldest son) and Bin hime (adopted by Hidetada TOKUGAWA and became the lawful wife of Tadaharu HORIO).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: いずれも正室本多氏の所生。
sen.e: Both were the birth children of his lawful wife from the Honda clan.
Both were the birth children of his lawful wife from the Honda clan.
Both were the real children of his lawful wife from the Honda clan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 官位は従四位下、大膳大夫、侍従。
sen.e: He was awarded the official rank of Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade) and appointed as Daizen no daibu (Master of the Palace Table) and served as jiju (a chamberlain).
He was awarded the official rank of Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade) and appointed as Daizen no daibu (Master of the Palace Table) and served as jiju (a chamberlain).
He was awarded the official rank of Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade and appointed as the Master of the Palace Table and served as a chamberlain.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 元服のとき、家康から一字をもらって家昌と名乗った。
sen.e: Upon genpuku (celebrate one's coming of age), he was given one character from Ieyasu and called himself Iemasa.
Upon genpuku (to celebrate one's coming of age), he was given one character from Ieyasu and called himself Iemasa.
Upon genpuku (to celebrate one's coming of age), he was given one character from the name of Ieyasu for his new name Iemasa.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 家康の外孫に当たる上に家康にとっても最年長の男孫であった事（叔父・秀忠よりも年長）から、刀や鷹を与えられるなど、重用された。
sen.e: For Ieyasu, Iemasa was not only a grandchild from a daughter married into another family but also the eldest grandson (he was older than his uncle Hidetada), so he was treated preferentially and given swords and hawks.

For Ieyasu, Iemasa was not only a grandchild from a daughter married into another family, but also the eldest grandson (he was older than his uncle Hidetada), so he was treated preferentially and given swords and hawks.

For Ieyasu, Iemasa was not only a grandchild from a daughter married into another family, but also the eldest grandson (he was older than his uncle Hidetada), so Ieyasu treated Iemasa preferentially and gave him swords and hawks.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 慶長6年2月6日 (旧暦)（1601年3月10日）、関ヶ原の戦勝後に命ぜられた京都治安活動を高く評価された父・信昌が美濃加納10万石を与えられた。
sen.e: On March 10, 1601, his father Nobumasa was awarded 100,000 koku in the Kano Domain, Mino Province as his public safety operation in Kyoto was highly evaluated after he won the Battle of Sekigahara.
On March 10, 1601, his father Nobumasa was awarded 100,000 koku in the Kano Domain, Mino Province as his public safety operation in Kyoto was highly evaluated after he won the Battle of Sekigahara.
On March 10, 1601, his father Nobumasa was awarded 100,000 koku in the Kano Domain, Mino Province in recognition of his public safety operation in Kyoto after the victory of the Battle of Sekigahara.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: そのため、それまでの上野国宮崎領に家昌を残し、父母は弟・奥平忠政を伴って配地へ赴任した。
sen.e: Therefore, his parents left Iemasa in Miyazaki, Kozuke Province for the designated place, taking his younger son Tadamasa OKUDAIRA together.
Therefore, his parents left Iemasa in Miyazaki, Kozuke Province for the designated place, taking his younger son Tadamasa OKUDAIRAr.
Therefore, his parents left Iemasa in Miyazaki, Kozuke Province for the appointed place with his younger brother Tadamasa OKUDAIRA.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 同年12月28日 (旧暦)（1602年2月19日）、家昌も父に遅れて、北関東の要地・下野宇都宮10万石を与えられると、翌月1月25日 (旧暦)（1602年3月18日）、入国を果たした。
sen.e: On February 19, 1602, after his father, he was awarded 100,000 koku in the Utsunomiya Domain, Shimotsuke Province, which was the key area in the Kita Kanto region (Northern Kanto), and entered the domain on March 18, 1602.

On February 19, 1602, after his father, he was awarded 100,000 koku in the Utsunomiya Domain, Shimotsuke Province, which was the key area in the Kita Kanto region (Northern Kanto), and entered the domain on March 18, 1602.

On February 19, 1602, subsequently to his father, he was awarded 100,000 koku in the Utsunomiya Domain, Shimotsuke Province, which was an strategic point in the Northern Kanto, and entered the domain on March 18, 1602.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 以後は、宇都宮藩の城下町整備に尽力。
sen.e: After that, he exerted himself to maintain the castle town of the Utsunomiya Domain.
After that, he endeavored to maintain the castle town of the Utsunomiya Domain.
After that, he devoted himself to develop the castle town of the Utsunomiya Domain.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 慶長16年10月13日 (旧暦)（1611年11月17日）、正室・本多氏（もり姫と言ったらしい）が死去した。
sen.e: On November 17, 1611, his lawful wife from the Honda clan (supposedly Mori hime) died.
On November 17, 1611, his lawful wife from the Honda clan (supposedly Mori hime) died.
On November 17, 1611, his lawful wife from the Honda clan (supposedly Mori hime) died.

sen.j: 宇都宮への転封後、三河時代からの家臣団制度が機能的でなくなったのを痛感した家昌は、重臣制度改正に着手した。
sen.e: After transferring to Utsunomiya, he strongly felt that the vassals system that had continued from the Mikawa era was no longer functioning, so he carried out reforms in the senior vassal system.
After transferring to Utsunomiya, he strongly felt that the vassal system that had continued from the Mikawa era was no longer functioning, so he carried out reforms in the senior vassal system.
After transferred to Utsunomiya, he strongly felt that the vassal system that had continued from the time in Mikawa does not work any longer, so he carried out reforms in the senior vassal system.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: この奥平家では長篠の戦いで父・信昌を援けた重臣12家を、『七族五老』と呼んでいた。
sen.e: In the Okudaira family, the senior vassals from 12 families who supported Iemasa's father Nobumasa in the Battle of Nagashino were called "Shichizoku goro."
In the Okudaira family, the senior vassals from 12 families who supported Iemasa's father, Nobumasa, in the Battle of Nagashino were called "Shichizoku goro."
In the Okudaira family, the senior vassals from 12 families, who worked hard for Iemasa's father Nobumasa in the Battle of Nagashino, were called "Shichizoku goro."
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 長篠の戦いの勝利後では陪臣でありながら家康から直々に労われた上に、彼らの子々孫々に至るまで厚遇を約束された御墨付きを拝領したという重臣達である。
sen.e: Although they were a vassal's retainers for Ieyasu, they received expression of appreciation for their efforts directly from Ieyasu after the victory in the Battle of Nagashino, and further won an endorsement of kind treatment for their successive generations.

Although they were a vassal's retainers for Ieyasu, they received an expression of appreciation for their efforts directly from Ieyasu after victory in the Battle of Nagashino, and further won an endorsement of kind treatment for their successive generations.

Although they were rear vassals of Ieyasu, they received an expression of recognition for their efforts directly from Ieyasu after the victory in the Battle of Nagashino, and further won an endorsement of kind treatment for their descendants.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 元々は跡継ぎと成れずに支族として宗家を支え、軍務を担当していた7家に、重臣に抜擢して政務を担当させた小領主たち5家を加えた12家の総称である。
sen.e: The total of 12 families were collectively called "Shichizoku goro," including the initial seven families that were unable to succeed the head family and thus supported the head family as branch families, being in charge of military affairs, and five families serving as small feudal lords selected as senior vassals in charge of governmental affairs.

The total of 12 families were collectively called "Shichizoku goro," including the initial seven families that were unable to succeed the head family and thus supported the head family as branch families, being in charge of military affairs, and five families serving as small feudal lords selected as senior vassals in charge of governmental affairs.

The total of 12 families were collectively called "Shichizoku goro," including the initial seven families that were unable to succeed the main family and thus supported the main family as branch families, being in charge of military affairs, and five families served as small feudal lords selected as senior vassals in charge of governmental affairs.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 戦乱に明け暮れた時勢であればまだしも、平穏な治世に移り変わっていくと、七族五老は軍務の負担が減る一方で政務の負担が激増していたのである。
sen.e: After the maelstrom of war was over, shifting to a peaceful reign, the burdens of military affairs on Shichizoku goro became reduced while the burdens of governmental affairs dramatically increased.
After the maelstrom of war was over, shifting to a peaceful reign, the burdens of military affairs on Shichizoku goro were reduced while the burdens of governmental affairs dramatically increased.

After the maelstrom of war was over with the transition to peaceful rule, the burdens of military affairs on Shichizoku goro were reduced while the burdens of governmental affairs dramatically increased.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: そこで、族臣7家と老臣5家を合一し『大身衆』と呼称変更させた上に、その12家の中から5、6家が毎月交代で国政を担当し、有事には12家が協力して対応するように改めたのである。
sen.e: Accordingly, Iemasa merged the seven vassal families with the five main retainer families and named "Taishinshu" (literally, people of high rank), and decided that five or six families out of 12 families alternately attend to the governmental affairs every month; 12 families cooperatively deal with emergency situations.

Accordingly, Iemasa merged the seven vassal families with the five main retainer families and named "Taishinshu" (literally, people of high rank), and decided that five or six families out of 12 families alternately attend to governmental affairs every month; 12 families cooperatively deal with emergency situations.

Accordingly, Iemasa merged the seven vassal families with the five main retainer families and named them "Taishinshu" (literally, people of high rank), and decided that five or six families out of twelve families alternately attend to governmental affairs every month; 12 families cooperatively deal with emergency situations.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: その12家は平等ではなく指導的立場にある2家が2000石以上を食み、序列によって俸禄が定められていた（末席でも1000石であった）。
sen.e: Those 12 families were not equally ranked but two families in leading positions were paid not less than 2,000 koku and the salaries were determined according to the ranks (1,000 koku was paid for the lowest ranking family).

Those 12 families were not equally ranked but two families in leading positions were paid not less than 2,000 koku and their salaries were determined according to their ranks (1,000 koku was paid for the lowest ranking family).

Those 12 families were not equally ranked and their salaries were determined according to their ranks; two families in leading positions were paid not less than 2,000 koku (1,000 koku was paid for the lowest ranking family).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: その指導的立場の山崎家と生田（しょうだ）家だけには、大手門内に邸宅を構えさせている。
sen.e: Only the families in the leading positions: the Yamazaki family and the Shoda family were permitted to build their houses inside the Ote-mon Gate.
Only the families in the leading positions: the Yamazaki family and the Shoda family were permitted to build their houses inside the Ote-mon Gate.
Only the families in the leading positions, the Yamazaki family and the Shoda family, were permitted to build their houses inside the Ote-mon Gate.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 父譲りの武勇を持っていたが、慶長19年10月6日 (旧暦)（1614年11月7日）、大坂の役大坂冬の陣のため出兵を命ぜられるも病を患い、遠征には不参となる。
sen.e: Iemasa had his father's bravery, but he suffered from disease when ordered to send troops to Osaka Fuyu no Jin (Winter Siege of Osaka) in Osaka no Eki (The Siege of Osaka) on November 7, 1614, so he did not participate in an expedition.

Iemasa had his father's bravery, but he suffered from a disease when ordered to send troops to Osaka Fuyu no Jin (Winter Siege of Osaka) in Osaka no Eki (The Siege of Osaka) on November 7, 1614, so he did not participate in the expedition.

Iemasa had his father's bravery, but he suffered from a disease when ordered to send troops to the Winter Siege of Osaka in the Siege of Osaka on November 7, 1614, so he did not participate in the expedition.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: その為、三日後の同月9日には出兵を免ぜられた分、鳥居忠政らと共に江戸城の本丸留守居役を仰せ付けられた。
sen.e: While exempted from dispatching the troops three days later on the 9th, he was ordered to serve as rusuiyaku (a person representing the master during his absence) at Honmaru (the keep of a castle) in Edo-jo Castle with Tadamasa TORII.

While exempted from dispatching the troops three days later on the 9th, he was ordered to serve as rusuiyaku (a person representing the master during his absence) at Honmaru (the keep of a castle) in Edo-jo Castle with Tadamasa TORII.

While exempted from dispatching the troops three days later on the 9th, he was ordered to serve as rusuiyaku (a person representing the master during his absence) at Honmaru (the keep of a castle) of Edo-jo Castle with Tadamasa TORII.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: ところが翌日10日、父母に先立って38歳の若さで死去。
sen.e: However, he died at the young age of 38 ahead of his parents next day on the 10th.
However, he died at the young age of 38 ahead of his parents the next day on the 10th.
However, he died at the young age of 38 before his parents the next day on the 10th.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 戒名は六通院殿天眼道高大禅定門。
sen.e: His Kaimyo (posthumous Buddhist names) was Rokutsu inden tengan doko daizenjomon.
His Kaimyo (posthumous Buddhist name) was Rokutsu inden tengan doko daizenjomon.
His posthumous Buddhist name was Rokutsu inden tengan doko daizenjomon.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 宇都宮藩領内の興禅寺 (宇都宮市)に葬られた。
sen.e: He was buried in Kozen-ji Temple (Utsunomiya City) in the Utsunomiya Domain.
He was buried in Kozen-ji Temple (Utsunomiya City) in the Utsunomiya Domain.
He was buried at Kozen-ji Temple (Utsunomiya City) in the Utsunomiya Domain.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 小鼓を嗜んだという。
sen.e: It is said that he enjoyed playing Kotsuzumi (small hand drum).
It is said that he enjoyed playing the Kotsuzumi (a small hand drum).
It is said that he enjoyed playing the Kotsuzumi (a small hand drum).
